choices.text: Vitamin B12

questions.text: Peripheral neuritis induced by isoniazid can be prevented by administration of which of the following vitamin along with it?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Vitamin B6

 

Option B:

 

Isoniazid, a commonly used anti-tubercular drug, is known to cause peripheral neuritis as a side effect, which is a form of nerve damage that results in pain, numbness, and tingling in the extremities. This neuropathy is due to isoniazid's interference with the metabolism of vitamin B6 (pyridoxine). Vitamin B6 is crucial for nerve function, and its deficiency can lead to neurological problems.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Vitamin B1: Incorrect. Vitamin B1 (thiamine) is important for neurological function but does not prevent isoniazid-induced peripheral neuritis.

 

Option C. Vitamin B3: Incorrect. Vitamin B3 (niacin) is not related to the prevention of peripheral neuritis associated with isoniazid.

 

Option D. Vitamin B12: Incorrect. While vitamin B12 is also important for neurological health, it does not specifically prevent the type of nerve damage caused by isoniazid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Isoniazid can interfere with the metabolism of vitamin B6, leading to a deficiency and the development of peripheral neuropathy. Therefore, the administration of vitamin B6 along with isoniazid can prevent or alleviate this adverse effect.

questions.text: Which of the following carbapenems has the highest potential to cause seizures?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Imipenem

 

Option A:

 

Imipenem is known to have the highest risk of inducing seizures among carbapenem antibiotics, particularly at high doses or in patients with underlying neurological disorders. This heightened risk is attributed to imipenem’s ability to cross the blood-brain barrier and its interaction with central nervous system neurotransmitters.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Ertapenem: Less likely to cause seizures compared to imipenem.

 

Option C. Doripenem: Also has a reduced risk of seizures relative to imipenem.

 

Option D. Meropenem: Known for its lower seizure-inducing potential compared to imipenem.

 

Educational Objective:

 

CARBAPENEMS

 

  • These include imipenem, doripenem, meropenem and ertapenem and faropenem.
  • These have wide spectrum of activity.
  • Carbapenems are beta-lactamase resistant and are drug of choice for Enterobacter, Klebsiella and Acinetobacter species.
  • These are only beta-lactams that are reliably efficacious against ESBL (extended spectrum beta-lactamase) producing organisms.
  • Imipenem is rapidly inactivated by renal dehydropeptidase I, so it is combined with cilastatin, an inhibitor of this enzyme. Cilastatin increases the half-life of imipenem.
  • Main adverse effects of imipenem-cilastatin combination include seizures and gastrointestinal distress.
  • Meropenem, doripenem and ertapenem are not metabolized by renal dehydropeptidase and are less likely to cause seizures.
  • Faropenem is the only carbapenem that can be given orally.

questions.text: A patient with a history of cancer is scheduled to undergo chemotherapy. Which of the following drugs is used for prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii in such patients?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Cotrimoxazole.

 

Option A:

 

Cotrimoxazole, a combination of trimethoprim and sulfamethoxazole, is widely used as prophylaxis against Pneumocystis jirovecii pneumonia (PJP), particularly in patients undergoing chemotherapy who are at increased risk for this opportunistic infection. Its dual action inhibits successive steps in the folate synthesis pathway of the organism, which is crucial for the production of nucleic acids and proteins. By preventing this infection, cotrimoxazole helps to reduce the risk of complications in immunocompromised individuals.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Amoxicillin: Incorrect. While amoxicillin is an antibiotic that treats bacterial infections, it is not effective against the fungus Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Option C. Dexamethasone: Incorrect. Dexamethasone is a corticosteroid used for inflammation and immune suppression, which could actually increase the risk of PJP rather than prevent it.

 

Option D. Cephalosporin: Incorrect. Cephalosporins are a class of antibiotics used against bacteria and do not have activity against Pneumocystis jirovecii.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Important Uses of Cotrimoxazole:

 

Punjab: Pneumocystis jiroveci

 

National: Nocardia

 

Bank: Burkholderia cepaciae

questions.text: Metronidazole is used for treatment of various anaerobic infections as well as bacterial vaginosis. Patient is instructed to avoid taking which of the following substances after metronidazole prescription to avoid possible adverse effects?
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Alcohol

 

Option C:

 

Metronidazole is an antibiotic commonly used for the treatment of anaerobic bacterial infections, including bacterial vaginosis, as well as some protozoal infections.

 

Alcohol should be avoided during and for at least 24 hours after completing a course of metronidazole, as the combination of the two can cause a disulfiram-like reaction, characterized by symptoms such as flushing, headache, nausea, vomiting, and palpitations.

 

This reaction occurs due to inhibition of aldehyde dehydrogenase, which leads to an accumulation of acetaldehyde, a toxic metabolite of alcohol, resulting in the unpleasant symptoms.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Grapefruit juice: Known to interact with several medications by affecting the cytochrome P450 enzymes, but metronidazole is not significantly affected by grapefruit juice.

 

Option B. Milk: There is no known interaction between metronidazole and milk.

 

Option D. Orange juice: There are no known interactions between metronidazole and orange juice.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Patients taking metronidazole should avoid alcohol to prevent a disulfiram-like reaction, which can result in uncomfortable and potentially severe symptoms due to the accumulation of acetaldehyde in the body.

 

Drugs that cause disulfiram like reaction are:

 

Cyclic   : Cefoperazone, Cefotetan, Cefamandole, Chlorpropamide

 

G          : Griesofulvin

 

M         : Metronidazole

 

P          : Procarbazine

questions.text: A 25-year-old patient with no significant medical history presents to the emergency department with a fever of 102°F and altered sensorium. Upon examination, you notice a petechial rash on the patient's arms and legs. You suspect meningococcal septicemia. Which of the following antibiotics is recommended as the first-line empiric therapy?
questions.solution:
Ans. A. Ceftriaxone

 

Option A:

 

Meningococcal septicemia is a life-threatening condition necessitating immediate medical intervention. The best empiric treatment in such a case, particularly in a young adult with symptoms indicating severe infection including fever, altered mental status, and petechial rash, is intravenous Ceftriaxone. This choice is driven by its broad-spectrum activity covering Neisseria meningitidis effectively and its ability to penetrate well into the central nervous system, providing rapid bacterial eradication.

 

Explanation:

 

Option B. Penicillin G: While it can be effective against Neisseria meningitidis, its use has diminished in many areas due to increased bacterial resistance patterns. It's considered an alternative if susceptibilities are known.

 

Option C. Piperacillin-Tazobactam: This antibiotic is primarily used for polymicrobial infections involving anaerobes and gram-negative bacteria and is not recommended for first-line treatment in meningococcal septicemia.

 

Option D. Cotrimoxazole: Typically used for specific parasitic and bacterial infections like Pneumocystis pneumonia and some types of staphylococcal infections, it is not effective as a first-line treatment for meningococcal infections.

 

Educational Objective:

 

DOC for empirical therapy of meningitis

 

 

Note:

 

  • Vancomycin is given to cover gram positive bacteria like Streptococcus pneumoniae and Staphylococcus (including MRSA)
  • Ampicillin is given to cover Listeria.
  • Meropenem is given to cover gram negative bacteria.
  • Cefotaxime can be used in place of ceftriaxone.
  • Cefepime can be used in place of meropenem.

choices.text: Results due to penicillinase enzyme production
Occurs due to change in penicillin binding proteins
Chromosome mediated
Treated with amoxicillin + clavulanic acid

questions.text: True statement regarding development of drug resistance in MRSA is?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Occurs due to change in penicillin binding proteins
 

Option B:

 

  • Methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) is a type of Staphylococcus aureus bacteria that has become resistant to methicillin and other beta-lactam antibiotics, such as penicillins and cephalosporins. This resistance occurs due to the acquisition of a mecA gene, which encodes for a penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) that has a lower affinity for beta-lactam antibiotics than the native PBPs in the bacteria.
  • This gene is carried on a mobile genetic element called the staphylococcal cassette chromosome (SCCmec), which can be transferred between bacteria via horizontal gene transfer. As a result, MRSA can develop resistance to multiple antibiotics over time, making it difficult to treat.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Results due to penicillinase enzyme production: Penicillinase enzyme production is a mechanism of resistance in some bacteria, but it is not the mechanism of resistance in MRSA.

 

Option C.  Chromosome mediated: While the resistance gene (mecA) is located on a mobile genetic element within the chromosome, the specific mechanism of resistance is the change in penicillin-binding proteins, making option B more directly relevant.

 

Option D. Treated with amoxicillin + clavulanic acid: Amoxicillin + clavulanic acid is not effective against MRSA. Infact no beta lactams (except 5th generation cephalosporins) are effective against MRSA. Antibiotics that are specifically active against MRSA include vancomycin, daptomycin, linezolid, or trimethoprim-sulfamethoxazole, among others.

 

Educational Objective:

 

MRSA’s resistance to beta-lactam antibiotics is primarily due to the mecA gene, which encodes a modified penicillin-binding protein (PBP2a) that does not bind these antibiotics effectively, allowing the bacteria to resist the effects of treatment that would otherwise inhibit cell wall synthesis. This mechanism is a critical aspect of understanding antibiotic resistance in clinical settings.

questions.text: Cobicistat is used along with which of the following antiretroviral drug?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Darunavir

 

Option B:

 

Cobicistat is primarily used as a pharmacokinetic enhancer rather than as an antiretroviral itself. It functions by inhibiting the CYP3A enzymes in the liver, which are responsible for metabolizing certain antiretroviral drugs like darunavir. By inhibiting these enzymes, cobicistat slows the breakdown of drugs such as darunavir, thereby increasing their plasma concentrations and enhancing their efficacy in controlling HIV infection.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Indinavir: Incorrect. While indinavir is a protease inhibitor used in the treatment of HIV, it is typically boosted by ritonavir, not cobicistat.

 

Option C. Ritonavir: Incorrect. Ritonavir itself is often used as a booster for other protease inhibitors due to its ability to inhibit CYP3A enzymes, similar to cobicistat, but it is not combined with cobicistat.

 

Option D. Saquinavir: Incorrect. Like indinavir, saquinavir is another protease inhibitor that is commonly boosted with ritonavir rather than cobicistat.

 

Additional Information:

 

  • Elvitegravir and cobicistat: Cobicistat is also used to enhance the effectiveness of elvitegravir, an integrase inhibitor, demonstrating its versatility in boosting various types of antiretroviral medications.
  • Use in combination therapies: Cobicistat is featured in combination antiretroviral therapies, where it is used to ensure optimal drug levels of protease inhibitors and other antiretrovirals to maximize their therapeutic impact while managing dosing frequency and potential side effects.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Cobicistat is used to enhance the effectiveness of antiretroviral drugs like darunavir by inhibiting enzymes that metabolize these drugs, thereby increasing their duration and concentration in the bloodstream.

 

This pharmacokinetic strategy is crucial for optimizing HIV therapy, particularly in patients who may benefit from simplified dosing regimens and improved drug efficacy.

questions.text: Which of the following drugs is useful in the treatment of infection caused by Mycobacterium avium complex?
questions.solution:
Ans. B. Clarithromycin

 

Option B:

 

Clarithromycin is a key drug in the treatment regimen for infections caused by Mycobacterium avium complex (MAC), a group of bacteria that can cause serious respiratory and systemic infections, especially in immunocompromised individuals like those with HIV/AIDS. It is effective because it inhibits bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 50S subunit of the bacterial ribosome.

 

Explanation:

 

Option A. Isoniazid: Primarily used for tuberculosis caused by Mycobacterium tuberculosis and not typically effective against MAC.

 

Option C. Cycloserine: Used as a second-line drug for resistant tuberculosis and not for MAC.

 

Option D. Rifampicin: While it has some activity against MAC, it is generally not used alone for effective management and is part of combination therapies for better efficacy.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Treatment of MAC infection is REC (Rifabutin + Ethambutol + Clarithromycin)
  • Clarithromycin alone can be used for the prophylaxis of MAC infections in HIV positive patients.
  • Azithromycin can also be used in place of clarithromycin.
